title: Jarred Ezra Randall
text:
I am a Miami-born, Philadelphia-based recent graduate of the Urban Spatial Analytics (MUSA) program with a concentration in Affordable Housing & Policy from the University of Pennsylvania. I hold a Bachelor’s degree in Landscape Architecture from the University of Florida and have professional experience as a Landscape Designer II. My background also includes working as a chef, which has equipped me with the ability to thrive in collaborative, deadline-driven work environments and effectively manage teams during stressful periods.
I have a strong interest in design as a means for social justice, equitable urban green space, green infrastructure, and community-driven design practices. My skill set includes proficiency in data-driven design, spatial analysis, GIS, data visualization, R, and Python programming. Throughout my career, I have demonstrated the ability to manage projects effectively, thrive in collaborative work environments, and provide excellent communication, time management, and a strong work ethic.



Lead various landscape design projects: Demonstrated strong project management skills, ensuring timely and successful project completion.
Conducted in-depth proposal research: Resulted in a higher project win rate by providing detailed and compelling project proposals.
Created innovative conceptual designs: Met client specifications and exceeded expectations through creativity and attention to detail.
Developed comprehensive hardscape and planting construction documents and details: Ensured accurate and detailed plans for implementation.
Coordinated with regulatory agencies: Ensured project compliance and smooth approval processes by liaising effectively with relevant authorities.
Produced high-quality graphic exhibits and renderings: Communicated design concepts effectively to clients and stakeholders.
Conducted survey fieldwork: Gathered essential data for project planning, contributing to informed and accurate design decisions.





Project Management: Effective in leading projects from conception to completion.
Design: Skilled in creating innovative and functional landscape designs.
Research: Proficient in conducting thorough proposal research and analysis.
Data-Driven Design: Expertise in spatial analysis and data visualization using GIS, R, and Python.
Collaboration: Thrive in collaborative work environments, working effectively with teams and stakeholders.




In my free time, I’m a musician and still an avid cook who loves to cook over an open fire. I have played in musical projects based in Gainesville, FL & Jamaica Plain, MA, including Kvetch, Tiny Farm, and Camp Hope. I enjoy going on hikes with my dog Ripley and am a big sports fan, especially of Miami teams like the Heat, Panthers, and Dolphins.



Meet Ripley!

title: Jarred Ezra Randall
A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text:
For an independent study in applications of remote sensing for sustainable urban planning, I used Google Earth Engine and global wetlands datasets to train a Random Forest model on Landsat 7 spectral images and assess wetlands change from 2000 to 2020.
My model achieved 95% accuracy and 65% recall, and suggests that the Iberá wetlands have declined significantly in the past 20 years.



Additionally, for a wetland ecology class, I put together a presentation on how remote sensing is used for wetland monitoring:

title: A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text: This project was completed as part of the Master of Urban Spatial Analytics (MUSA) program practicum, where students collaborate with real-world clients to develop data science tools that help stakeholders better allocate their limited resources.

title: A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text:
Project Overview

    
        
    

This project was completed as part of the UPENN Master of Urban Spatial Analytics (MUSA) program practicum, where students collaborate with real-world clients to develop data science tools that help stakeholders better allocate resources. My team worked closely with the Watauga Housing Council to develop a data-driven application that leverages spatial analysis to identify parcels most suitable for development in Watauga County, North Carolina. This project addressed the critical issue of affordable and workforce housing in a region with challenging geographical and economic conditions. Because of the rural location, Watauga County has limited wastewater sewage connections, making septic permits essential for new development. To streamline the site selection process, we analyzed the physical and spatial characteristics of parcels that had successfully obtained septic permits in the past, targeting undeveloped parcels with similar attributes. Our application provides actionable insights, empowering the Watauga Housing Council to make informed decisions and strategically plan for sustainable housing development.
Click any image to read the full report on RPubs, detailing our methodologies, findings, and the application’s impact.

title: MUSA Practicum Project: A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text:
The Challenge
Watauga County, located in a rural area of North Carolina, faces unique geographical and economic challenges in developing affordable housing. The limited wastewater sewage connections mean that septic permits are essential for new developments, adding a layer of complexity to site selection for housing projects.

title: MUSA Practicum Project: A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text:
Our Solution
Our team, working closely with the Watauga Housing Council, developed a data-driven application leveraging advanced spatial analysis. We focused on identifying undeveloped parcels that mirrored the physical and spatial characteristics of parcels that had successfully obtained septic permits in the past.

title: MUSA Practicum Project: A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text:
Impact of Our Work
The application we developed provides the Watauga Housing Council with actionable insights, empowering them to make informed decisions and strategically plan for sustainable housing development. This tool helps address the critical issue of affordable and workforce housing in the region, ensuring that resources are utilized effectively and developments are feasible.

title: MUSA Practicum Project: A Planning Support Tool for Affordable and Workforce Housing Site Identification
text:
Further Reading
Click the image below to read the full report on RPubs, detailing our methodologies, findings, and the application’s impact.

title: Amsterdam in Balance: Data-Driven Strategies for Managing Overtourism and Short-Term Rentals
text:
Project Overview
This study examines the impact of overtourism in Amsterdam and explores data-driven strategies for managing short-term rentals. The project focuses on the implementation and outcomes of regulatory measures, and the role of the Fairbnb app in ensuring compliance and promoting fair rental practices.

    
        
    

This project was completed as part of the Public Policy Analytics course at UPENN, where students analyze real-world issues using data science tools. My partner, Nohman Akharti, and I collaborated to deliver comprehensive insights into the challenges and opportunities presented by Amsterdam’s tourist boom. By leveraging a variety of data sources, including Airbnb activity, housing market trends, and regulatory impacts, we developed models to predict the effects of different policy measures on local housing and tourism dynamics.
Click any image to read the full report on RPubs, detailing our methodologies, findings, and the broader implications of our analysis.

title: Predictive Urban Planning for 2031: Analyzing Development Trends in Atlanta
text:
Project Overview
This study forecasts urban development in Atlanta for the year 2031 using historical land use data, demographic changes, and transportation dynamics from 2011 to 2021. We employed a binary logistic regression model to predict future development patterns, supporting the Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) in strategic planning for sustainable growth.

    
    Download the Poster


This project was completed as part of the Land Use and Environmental Modeling course at UPENN. My partner, Sylvanus Duamor, and I analyzed development trends to provide actionable insights for the Atlanta MPO. By leveraging various data sources, we developed models to predict the effects of different policy measures on future urban growth.

    
    Download the MEMO

title: Policy Analysis and Recommendation Writing Samples
section: Policy Brief: Miami Beach Flood Inundation Modeling & Planning Center
text:
Policy Brief: Miami Beach Flood Inundation Modeling & Planning Center
This policy brief, completed for the Land Use and Environmental Modeling course (CPLN 6750 / MUSA 6750), proposes the establishment of a Flood Inundation Modeling & Planning Center (FIMPC) in Miami Beach to mitigate the impacts of flooding through advanced planning, modeling, and community engagement.

    
    Download the Policy Brief

title: Policy Analysis and Recommendation Writing Samples
section: Budget Analysis: City of Miami Affordable Housing Master Plan
text:
Budget Analysis: City of Miami Affordable Housing Master Plan
This budget analysis, conducted for the Housing policy course (CPLN 644), assesses the financial mechanisms and strategic initiatives outlined in the Miami Affordable Housing Master Plan aimed at addressing the city’s critical affordable housing crisis.

    
    Download the Policy Brief

title: Policy Analysis and Recommendation Writing Samples
section: Policy Paper: Proposal for Adoption of Small Area Fair Market Rent (SAFMR)
text:
Policy Paper: Proposal for Adoption of Small Area Fair Market Rent (SAFMR)
This policy paper, also for the Housing Policy course (CPLN 644), proposes the adoption of the Small Area Fair Market Rent (SAFMR) approach by Miami-Dade County to improve housing voucher allocations and address housing inequality effectively.

    
    Download the Policy Brief

title: Targeting a Housing Subsidy: A Data-Driven Approach
text:
Project Overview
This project was completed as part of the Public Policy Analytics course at UPENN. Emil City is considering a more proactive approach for targeting homeowners who qualify for a home repair tax credit program. This analysis aimed to train the best classifier to predict which homeowners are most likely to accept the credit and use the results to inform a cost/benefit analysis. By leveraging historical campaign data, we developed models to predict homeowners’ likelihood of accepting the subsidy and conducted a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis. The goal was to optimize resource allocation and increase participation in the credit program.

    
        
    

Click any image to read the full report on RPubs, detailing our methodologies and findings.

title: Exploring Digital Equity: A Geospatial Analysis of the Digital Divide
text:
Project Overview
This project was completed as part of the MUSA 550 Geospatial Data Science In Python course at UPENN. Our team sought to understand the varied digital equity landscape at the international, federal, and state levels through geospatial data analysis. By leveraging a cell tower location database from OpenCellID, we analyzed digital equity through questions such as: What international metrics inform digital equity in developed vs. developing countries? Is there equitable access to ICT technology across the United States? How does the digital divide persist in rural vs. urban areas?

    
        
    

Our exploratory analysis included creating data visualizations that condensed over 200 million data points into actionable insights. These visualizations provided a global understanding of cell tower coverage and highlighted the disparities in digital access. The findings from this project contribute valuable insights to the ongoing conversation about bridging the digital divide and ensuring equitable access to technology on a global scale.
Click any image to read the full report, detailing our methodologies, findings, and the broader implications of our analysis

title: Policy Analysis and Recommendation Writing Samples
section: Statistical Writing: OLS Regression Analysis of Home Values in Philadelphia
text:
Statistical Writing: OLS Regression Analysis of Home Values in Philadelphia
This statistical writing sample, completed for an assignment in the Quantitative Methods course, presents an Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression analysis investigating the variation in median home sales prices for Census block groups in Philadelphia. The analysis examines the correlation between median home values and predictive variables such as education, vacancy rates, housing types, and poverty levels.

    
    Download the Statistical Writing Sample

title: Design for Distressed Public Housing: Creating Supportive Living Environments through Outdoor Public Spaces
text:
Project Overview
This capstone project was completed as part of the Landscape Architecture undergraduate program at the University of Florida. The project explores how landscape architects can use outdoor public spaces to create supportive living environments for residents of severely distressed public housing. The project focuses on addressing the physical and social issues that contribute to the distress in public housing, such as physical deterioration, crime, residential distress, and high concentrations of poverty. Through design interventions in outdoor spaces, the project aims to provide relief for residents and create a more supportive living environment until more suitable housing options are available.

    
    Download the Capstone Project

title: Bachelor of Landscape Architecture Portfolio
text:
Project Overview
This portfolio showcases a selection of projects completed as part of my Bachelor of Landscape Architecture (BLA) program at the University of Florida. The projects demonstrate my skills in urban design, site planning, and landscape construction, highlighting my ability to create functional, aesthetic, and sustainable outdoor spaces.
This document includes a variety of design projects, such as urban plazas, stormwater management systems, and community parks. Each project reflects a comprehensive approach to landscape architecture, combining innovative design principles with practical solutions to address environmental and social challenges.

    
    Download the Portfolio
